data.Name: Isotope, Non-Gas
data.Description: DEPRECATED: Please use Code="Isotope.NonGas" with Name="Isotope, Non Gas" instead. Isotope analysis (for example, d13C, dD, d34S) of a bulk sample, which might be a whole oil, saturate fraction, water, rock, etc.

data.Name: Elemental Composition, EDS-Mapping
data.Description: DEPRECATED: Please use Code="ElementalComposition.EDSMapping" with Name="Elemental Composition, EDS Mapping" instead. Elemental Dispersive Spectroscopy technique applied to the surface of a thin section.

data.Name: Wettability, Amott-Harvey
data.Description: DEPRECATED: Please use Code="Wettability.AmottHarvey" with Name="Wettability, Amott Harvey" instead. Experiment which measures the interaction between two fluids and the rock sample surface by comparing the spontaneous imbibition of the two fluids.

data.Name: Wettability, Amott-USBM
data.Description: DEPRECATED: Please use Code="Wettability.AmottUSBM" with Name="Wettability, Amott USBM" instead. Experiment which measures the interaction between two fluids and the rock sample surface by utilising the ratio of drainage to imbibition capillary pressure curves.

data.Name: Stratigraphy, Core Description
data.Description: DEPRECATED: Please use Code="CoreDescription" with Name="Core Description" instead. Written and/or diagrammatic representation of the core to describe the lithologies, minerals, fractures, fossils, and structure of the core

data.Name: Basic Rock Properties, Crushed Rock Analysis
data.Description: Basic rock properties evaluated on an intact plug sample via a Crushed Rock Analysis technique that may or may not include porosity, air permeability, water/gas/oil saturations, grain density, bulk density, plug volumetrics and weights. Crushed rock method should be specified in the remarks: GRI, TruSat, etc

data.Name: Basic Rock Properties, Retort
data.Description: Basic rock properties evaluated on an intact plug sample via a crushed rock retort technique that may include porosity, air permeability, klinkenberg permeability, water/gas/oil saturations, grain density, bulk density, plug volumetrics and weights

data.Name: Basic Rock Properties, Routine Core Analysis
data.Description: Basic rock properties evaluated on an intact plug sample via a Routine Core Analysis (RCA) technique that may include porosity, air permeability, klinkenberg permeability, water/gas/oil saturations, grain density, bulk density, plug volumetrics and weights through various individual methods like Boyle's Law, brine saturation, Klinkenberg correction, and Dean Stark.

data.Name: Basic Rock Properties, Digital Rock Modelling
data.Description: Starting with scans or photography (e.g. CT) of physical samples, various digital models can be created and run to measure different properties digitally. Measurements often include pore scale modelling. Other existing measured data can be used to calibrate such a digital rock model.

data.Name: Basic Rock Properties
data.Description: Basic Rock Properties with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.

data.Name: Basic Rock Properties, Probe Permeameter
data.Description: Permeability measurements acquired through the use of a handheld permeameter device, also called a probe, held to the surface of a core sample

data.Name: Capillary Pressure, Centrifuge
data.Description: Capillary pressure curve derived using variable speed centrifuge to expel saturated fluid. This experiment can replicate drainage function (where the displacing fluid is oil or gas displacing water) or imbibition (water dispacing oil or gas).

data.Name: Capillary Pressure, Mercury Injection
data.Description: Also known as MICP or HPMI (High Pressure Mercury Injection). Results of a capillary pressure experiment where mercury is forced into a core sample. The result is a measurement of volume of mercury injected as a function of pressure required; One result of this experiment is pore throat size distribution.

data.Name: Capillary Pressure, Research and Development Method
data.Description: This value should be applied when the analysis method is not broadly known by the industry; For example, one service company or one operator is testing a new experimental method. It is expected that if a particular analysis method eventually becomes broadly used by the industry, that it will be contributed to the OSDU Forum and added to this SampleAnalysisType reference list.

data.Name: Capillary Pressure, Porous Plate
data.Description: Capillary pressure curve derived using pressure as the displacement mechanism. The experiment can replicate drainage (oil displacing water) or imbibition (using an oil saturated sample with water displacing the oil). The fluids can be oil/water or gas/water.

data.Name: Capillary Pressure, Digital Rock Modelling
data.Description: Starting with scans or photography (e.g. CT) of physical samples, various digital models can be created and run to measure different properties digitally. Measurements often include pore scale modelling. Other existing measured data can be used to calibrate such a digital rock model.

data.Name: Capillary Pressure
data.Description: CapillaryPressure with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.

data.Name: Electrical Properties, Cation Exchange Capacity
data.Description: This is one measurement of clay conductivity emanating from the cation exchange capacity of clay minerals in the sample. Usually measured in meq/gm. This is one measurement of clay conductivity. Commonly called CEC. Captures Qv.

data.Name: Electrical Properties, CoCw
data.Description: This is one measurement of clay conductivity. This captures the conductivity of a water-saturated core plug (Co), and a conductivity of simulated brines (Cw). The experiment is done using multiple salinities of water.

data.Name: Electrical Properties, Resistivity Index
data.Description: Ratio of sample resistivity (Rt) at a given fluid saturation (Sw) to the sample at fully fluid saturated state (Ro). This provides Archie's saturation exponent, commonly referred to as "n". PCRI is a common method of measuring this property.

data.Name: Electrical Properties
data.Description: ElectricalProperties with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.

data.Name: Electrical Properties, Digital Rock Modelling
data.Description: Starting with scans or photography (e.g. CT) of physical samples, various digital models can be created and run to measure different properties digitally. Measurements often include pore scale modelling. Other existing measured data can be used to calibrate such a digital rock model.

data.Name: Electrical Properties, Formation Resistivity Factor
data.Description: Ratio of sample resistivity to brine resistivity. This provides Archie's cementation exponent, commonly referred to as "m". Formation Resistivity Factor is often abbreviated FRF.

data.Name: Extraction
data.Description: Extraction with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily. Extraction contains properties (captured in the DDMS) for extraction methods including soxhlet, high pressure/high temperature, Dean Stark, etc. and generally include weight of rock, weight of extract, and calculated derivative properties.

data.Name: Flow Assurance Properties, Asphaltene
data.Description: Asphaltene related Flow Assurance Properties such as Asphaltene Onset Pressure, Asphaltene Content, Asphaltene Deposition Rates, etc. Measured from Live Oil. This is for properties measured with methods other than Crude Assay (see Stock Tank Oil Characterization for Crude Assay).

data.Name: Flow Assurance Properties, Chemical Screening
data.Description: Chemical-screening measurements for stability and inhibition. Measured from Dead Oil or Live Oil.

data.Name: Flow Assurance Properties, Emulsion
data.Description: Emulsion-related Flow Assurance Properties. Measured from Dead Oil or Live Oil.

data.Name: Flow Assurance Properties, Hydrate
data.Description: Hydrate-related Flow Assurance Properties. Measured from Live Oil.

data.Name: Flow Assurance Properties, Inorganic Scale
data.Description: Inorganic Scale-related Flow Assurance Properties. Measured from Dead Oil or Live Oil.

data.Name: Flow Assurance Properties, Naphthenate
data.Description: Naphthenate-related Flow Assurance Properties. Measured from Dead Oil or Live Oil.

data.Name: Flow Assurance Properties, Rheology
data.Description: Measurement of Rheological properties of liquids, solids, and slurries. Measured from Dead Oil or Live Oil.

data.Name: Flow Assurance Properties, Wax
data.Description: Wax related Flow Assurance Properties such as WAT, Wax Content (different methods), Wax Deposition, Gel Strength, etc. Measured from Dead Oil or Live Oil.  This is for properties measured with methods other than Crude Assay (see Stock Tank Oil Characterization for Crude Assay).

data.Name: Fluid Inclusion
data.Description: Data included in this category includes fluid inclusion petrography (textural relationships), microthermometry (to determine homogenization temperatures), etc. Screening analysis, commonly referred to as fluid inclusion volatiles (FIV) or fluid inclusion stratigraphy is represented as a well log, and is not captured with sample-based data.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Gas Chromatography
data.Description: Two-dimensional gas chromatography (GC×GC) is a multidimensional gas chromatography technique that utilizes two chromatographic columns with different stationary phases. In GC×GC, all of the effluent from the first dimension column is diverted to the second dimension column via a modulator. The modulator quickly traps, then "injects" the effluent from the first dimension column onto the second dimension. This process creates a retention plane of the 1st dimension separation x 2nd dimension separation.

data.Name: Gamma Ray, Core Gamma Ray
data.Description: Gamma Ray measured on a specimen, usually core. In some cases it can be measured on non-core rock samples.

data.Name: Isotope, Compound Specific Isotope Analysis
data.Description: Compound specific isotope analysis (CSIA) is the measurement of isotope ratios (typically, the stable isotope ratios of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur) of individual compounds extracted from rocks and fluids. The compounds are separated by gas chromatography and then oxidized or pyrolysed to produce simple gases (H2, CO2, CO, N2, O2, SO2) suitable for analysis by a gas-source isotope-ratio mass spectrometer.

data.Name: Isotope, Gas
data.Description: Isotope analysis (for example, d13C, dD) of a gas sample,where individual components (methane, ethane, etc.) are first separated then isotopic value for each fraction is determined

data.Name: PVT, Compositional Analysis
data.Description: This dataset contains properties (captured in the DDMS) that generally include mole and mass percents of: total fluid, flashed gas and flashed liquid, and individual components (e.g., C1, C2, C3…). These compositional data for the flashed liquid and gas streams together with Single Stage Flash Volumtric data are used to report out overall fluid composition.

data.Name: PVT, Constant Composition Expansion
data.Description: A constant composition expansion (CCE) is an isothermal test that establishes the pressure/volume relationship for a fluid system as it may be depleted in a reservoir. Measurements of this test include saturation pressure, relative volume, single-phase densities, and other details depending on fluid type, for example, compressibility (oil), deviation factors (gas), and liquid dropout (condensates) as a fluid sample is progressively allowed to expand with decreasing pressure without removing any of the sample.

data.Name: PVT, Constant Volume Depletion
data.Description: Constant volume depletion (CVD) is a test to simulate the production of a retrograde gascondensate system through the depletion of the reservoir below the dew point. The test simulates what occurs when the liquid dropout stays in the reservoir and the surface production stream becomes leaner relative to the single-phase system. Deliverables from this test include well stream compositions below the dew point and the average liquid yields, Z-Factor, as the fluid system is produced to abandonment pressure.

data.Name: PVT, Differential Liberation
data.Description: Differential liberation is a test to simulate the depletion of a black-oil or volatile-oil reservoir system at a constant reservoir temperature. This test is designed to measure what happens to the reservoir fluid as it is depleted below the bubble point—at which point evolved gas begins to flow segregated from the oil. Measurements from this test include formation volume factors for oil and gas and the solution gas-oil ratios and viscosities below saturation pressure.

data.Name: PVT, Interfacial Tension
data.Description: Interfacial tension tests measure the interfacial tension between two phases. These are labelled the wetting phase and the non-wetting phase. A surfactant can also be defined. Each test step reports the interfacial tension and optionally, the surfactant concentration.

data.Name: PVT, Multi-Contact Miscibility
data.Description: The test involves multiple contact of a fixed amount of gas with multiple fresh charges of an oil sample, where intermediate components from the oil sample are stripped consecutively (forward contact). In case of a backward contact test, a fixed charge of an oil sample will come in contact with multiple charges of fresh rich gas, so that intermediate components in the gas phase are transferred to the oil phase. The process continues until miscibility is achieved. During each contact, the composition of each phase is measured.

data.Name: PVT, Multi-Stage Separator Test
data.Description: A separator test mimics the processing of produced fluids through one or more stages of separation. Primarily for black-oil and volatile-oil fluid systems, the results of this test are formation volume factors and densities, shrinkages, API gravity, and producing GOR that are used both in reservoir engineering calculations and facilities design.

data.Name: PVT, Sample Integrity
data.Description: The initial description of a fluid sample is handled as a distinct test type. The data captured includes opening pressures, volumes and phases present, gas-oil ratios (GORs), densities and/or specific gravities. Contaminants or other adverse characteristics may be identified within the fluid sample, and the laboratory may conduct and record additional steps to make the fluid sample more representative of the in-situ reservoir fluid or stock tank oil.

data.Name: PVT, Saturation Test
data.Description: a saturation test is a test in which bubble or dew point pressure of liquid or a gas system is determined at a constant temperature.

data.Name: PVT, Single-Stage Flash
data.Description: An atmospheric flash takes the reservoir fluid to stock tank conditions, producing a dead oil sample and a gas sample. These samples are used to measure basic properties like the oil’s API gravity, the gas-oil ratio, and the compositions of the oil and gas.

data.Name: PVT, Slim Tube
data.Description: A slim tube test is used to study the miscibility condition of a reservoir oil sample when it comes in contact with a gas sample flowing inside a long tube filled with sand (porous media) in a near one-dimensional flow condition. In general, a number of slim tube tests are performed at constant temperature with varying pressures to determine the minimum pressure at which miscibility is achieved after injection of certain pore volume of gas.

data.Name: PVT, Solubility Swelling
data.Description: Swelling test is a series of constant composition expansion tests, in each of which an increasing amount of particular injection gas is added to a reservoir oil sample at fixed temperature. In each expansion test, saturation pressure and physical and transport properties of the mixture (density and viscosity) can be determined.

data.Name: PVT, Stock Tank Oil Characterization
data.Description: The result of running a Crude Assay. For representative samples of stock tank oil, an additional set of stock tank oil (STO) analysis tests may be conducted to provide measurements of viscosity (at temperature), pour point, cloud point, wax appearance temperature, paraffin content, Reid vapor pressure, total acid number, total sulfur, molecular weight, water content, and the amounts of lead, nickel, vanadium and elemental sulfur present. Note that in OSDU, StockTankOilCharacterization does not include SARA and High Temperature GC; those have their own SampleAnalysisTypes. Also, other forms of Elemental Composition are captured in the Elemental Composition Family.

data.Name: PVT, Transport Properties
data.Description: This test is to assess the properties of the fluid relevant to transportation. A series of test steps for properties (such as viscosity, density, etc.) can be defined

data.Name: PVT, Vapor Liquid Equilibria
data.Description: In this test, a mixture of oil and injection gas is equilibrated in a fixed condition of pressure and temperature where two distinct vapor and liquid phases are present. Properties of each phase (composition, density, viscosity) are also used to optimize an equation-of-state model to represent phase equilibria during gas injection EOR process.

data.Name: Water Analysis
data.Description: Including properties captured in the DDMS like: Color, TDS (Total Dissolved Solids), TSS (Total Suspended Solids), Salinity, Resistivity, FreeChlorine, WeakBases, Bicarbonate, SulfurTotal, abundance of individual anions and cations. Note that this analysis represents water analyses historically captured in the geochemistry databases and water analyses reported in PVT reports. (Note that water isotopes are captured in a separate Isotope.Non-Gas category.)

data.Name: Elemental Composition, ICPMS
data.Description: ICP (Inductively Coupled Plasma) Spectroscopy is an analytical technique used to measure and identify elements within a sample matrix based on the ionization of the elements withing the sample. Mass Spectrometer (MS) separates the ions out by their mass-to-charge ratio after going through the ICP, and the detector counts the number of selected ions per second which allows the instrument to determine the concentration of each chosen element.

data.Name: Elemental Composition, Combustion
data.Description: Total Organic Carbon (TOC) measured using a combustion method that is not pyrolysis. Usually the results also include sulfur and inorganic carbon. This is used in both organic chemistry and analytical chemistry to determine the elemental composition (more precisely empirical formula) of a pure organic compound by combusting the sample under conditions where the resulting combustion products can be quantitatively analyzed. LECO is a common method. (Note that HAWK is not ElementalComposition; Please use Pyrolysis.Bulk for HAWK analysis including TOC.)

data.Name: Elemental Composition
data.Description: ElementalComposition with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.

data.Name: Elemental Composition, XRF
data.Description: The expanded full name is X-ray Fluorescence. XRF is an analytical technique that uses the interaction of X-rays with a material to determine its elemental composition. This could be measured continuously, or in smaller pieces using a handheld device.

data.Name: Fractionation, SARA
data.Description: Measurements of the relative abundance saturate, aromatic, resin, and asphaltene (SARA) fractions in an oil or extract. Separation is accomplished by various methods including Open Column, High Performance Liquid Chromatography, Thin Layer Chromatography, etc.  Preparation steps could include processes like Topping and Precipitation.

data.Name: Fractionation
data.Description: Fractionation is the separation of the component parts, or fractions, of petroleum according to various differentiating properties. Fractionation with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or, c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.")

data.Name: Gas Chromatography, Aromatic
data.Description: Relative abundance hydrocarbon compounds in the n-C4 to n-C42 carbon range by injecting microliter volumes of the separated aromatic fraction into a split/splitless injector of a gas chromatograph (GC). The aromatic fraction is generally isolated first by liquid chromatography. A capillary column is used to provide separation of the  for detection by a flame ionization detector (FID).

data.Name: Gas Chromatography, Gas Composition
data.Description: Relative abundance of hydrocarbon (e.g., methane, ethane, propane) and non-hydrocarbon (e.g., carbon dioxide, hydrogen sulfide) gases measured using gas chromatography.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography, Gasoline
data.Description: Gasoline-range hydrocarbon abundance measured using GasChromatography. Results are generally reported in peak heights and/or peak areas for individual compound peaks such as normal alkanes, methylcyclohexanes, toluene, benzene, etc.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography, High Temperature
data.Description: Also known as HTGC. High temperature hydrocarbon abundance measured using GasChromatography. Results are generally reported in peak heights and/or peak areas for individual compound peaks such as normal alkanes and include higher carbon number "waxy" alkanes  (nC40+)

data.Name: Gas Chromatography, Pyrolysis
data.Description: Pyrolysis gas chromatography (GC) is generally used for the categorization of polymers. During pyrolysis, which is usually performed at ∼700°C, large molecules are broken up into smaller ones which are then separated by GC.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography, Saturate
data.Description: Also known as GC Alkanes. Relative abundance hydrocarbon compounds in the n-C4 to n-C42 carbon range by injecting microliter volumes of the separated saturate fraction into a split/splitless injector of a gas chromatograph (GC). The saturate fraction is generally isolated first by liquid chromatography. A capillary column is used to provide separation of the  for detection by a flame ionization detector (FID).

data.Name: Gas Chromatography, Simulated Distillation
data.Description: Simulated distillation is used to determine the true boiling point distribution of crude oil and petroleum refining fractions by gas-liquid chromatography.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography, Sulfur Detection
data.Description: Relative abundance sulfur-bearing hydrocarbon compounds by injecting microliter volumes of an oil or extract into a split/splitless injector of a gas chromatograph (GC).  A capillary column is used to provide separation of the  for detection by a flame photometric detector (FPD).

data.Name: Gas Chromatography, Thermal Extraction
data.Description: Relative abundance hydrocarbon compounds introduced to a gas chromatograph by thermal desorption from a solid sample.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography, Whole Oil
data.Description: Relative abundance hydrocarbon compounds in the n-C4 to n-C42 carbon range by injecting microliter volumes of the whole oil or extract into a split/splitless injector of a gas chromatograph (GC). A capillary column is used to provide separation of the  for detection by a flame ionization detector (FID).

data.Name: Gas Chromatography
data.Description: Gas chromatography (GC) is the process of separating compounds in a mixture by injecting a gaseous or liquid sample into a mobile phase, typically called the carrier gas, and passing the gas through a stationary phase.  GasChromatography with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.")

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy, Aromatic
data.Description: Qualitative and quantitative abundance of aromatic compounds (e.g., phenanthrenes and naphthalenes) in crude oils and extracts. The sample is separated on capillary column, and as each peak elutes, the mass spectrometer breaks each molecule into ionized fragments and detects these fragments using their mass-to-charge ratio.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy, Diamondoid
data.Description: Qualitative and quantitative abundance of diamondoid compounds, found in mature high-temperature petroleum fluids. The sample is separated on capillary column, and as each peak elutes, the mass spectrometer breaks each molecule into ionized fragments and detects these fragments using their mass-to-charge ratio.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy, Pyrolysis
data.Description: Qualitative and quantitative abundance of compounds, where the sample is first heated to decomposition to produce smaller molecules (pyrolysate). The pyrolysate is separated on capillary column, and as each peak elutes, the mass spectrometer breaks each molecule into ionized fragments and detects these fragments using their mass-to-charge ratio.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy, Saturate
data.Description: Also know as GCMS Alkanes. Qualitative and quantitative abundance of saturate compounds (e.g., terpanes, steranes) in crude oils and extracts. The sample is separated on capillary column, and as each peak elutes, the mass spectrometer breaks each molecule into ionized fragments and detects these fragments using their mass-to-charge ratio.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy, Tandem Mass Spectroscopy
data.Description: Gas Chromatography–Tandem Mass spectrometry (GC-MS-MS) couples a Gas Chromatograph (GC) with two Mass Spectrometers which increases detail in molecular structure analysis.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy, ThermalExtract
data.Description: Samples collected and concentrated via thermal desorption are transferred to a GC column and then analyzed via mass spectrometry. This technique accesses much of the organic matter that is not accessible via traditional liquid extraction techniques.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy
data.Description: GasChromatographyMassSpectroscopy (GCMS) is composed of two major building blocks: the gas chromatograph (GC) and the mass spectrometer (MS). GCMS with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.")

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy Mass Spectroscopy
data.Description: Gas Chromatography–Tandem Mass spectrometry (GC-MS-MS) couples a Gas Chromatograph (GC) with two Mass Spectrometers which increases detail in molecular structure analysis. GC-MS-MS with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.")

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy Mass Spectroscopy, QQQ
data.Description: A triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (TQMS), is a tandem mass spectrometer consisting of two quadrupole mass analyzers in series, with a (non-mass-resolving) radio frequency (RF)–only quadrupole between them to act as a cell for collision-induced dissociation. This configuration is often abbreviated QQQ. One of the more common uses of a triple quadrupole mass analyzer is for structural elucidation, which provides information about fragmentation patterns.

data.Name: Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy Mass Spectroscopy, MRM
data.Description: Multiple Reaction Monitoring, (MRM) also called Selected Reaction Monitoring (SRM), is a method used in tandem mass spectrometry in which an ion of a particular mass is selected in the first stage of a tandem mass spectrometer and an ion product of a fragmentation reaction of the precursor ions is selected in the second mass spectrometer stage for detection.

data.Name: Geomechanics, Index Test
data.Description: Index tests measure physical properties of rocks that can be correlated to elasticity and strength. Common types in index tests include *Hardness* tests and *Scratch* tests.

data.Name: Geomechanics, Tensile Strength Analysis
data.Description: Tensile strength tests provide a measure of rock strength

data.Name: Geomechanics, Triaxial Strength Testing
data.Description: Triaxial compressive strength tests provide a number of measurements for applications to drilling and completions, including: "static" elastic moduli (Young's modulus and Poisson's ratio), strength parameters (UCS, cohesion, friction angle), ultrasonic velocities, and in some cases additional parameters (e.g. dilatancy, residual strength).

data.Name: Geomechanics, Uniaxial Testing
data.Description: Uniaxial compression tests can refer to two different tests, depending on the boundary conditions. Uniaxial strain tests typically provide measurements of compressibility, elastic moduli, and the stress path coefficient. Uniaxial stress tests are another name for unconfined compressive strength tests.

data.Name: Geomechanics, Compressibility
data.Description: Compressibility measurements are core analysis tests typically applied to reservoir simulation - pore volume compressibility, bulk volume compressibility, formation compressibility, and other such measurements.  These measurements should be done under stress and pressure conditions that simulate depletion and/or injection.

data.Name: Geomechanics, CoreLog
data.Description: Core Log measurements include petrophysical and geomechanics properties, typically reported as continuous (or nearly so) functions of depth or pseudo logs. Examples include ultrasonic velocities and unconfined compressive strength derived from the Scratch test.

data.Name: Geomechanics, Thermal
data.Description: Measurements of basic thermal physical properties including thermal expansion coefficient, specific heat, and thermal conductivity.

data.Name: Geomechanics, Research And Development Method
data.Description: This value should be applied when the analysis method is not broadly known by the industry; For example, one service company or one operator is testing a new experimental method. It is expected that if a particular analysis method eventually becomes broadly used by the industry, that it will be contributed to the OSDU Forum and added to this SampleAnalysisType reference list.

data.Name: Geomechanics
data.Description: Geomechanics with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.

data.Name: Mineralogy, FTIR
data.Description: Mineralogy determined via Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy methodology. Also known as FTIR.

data.Name: Mineralogy, Hyperspectral Analysis
data.Description: Mineralogy determined via hyperspectral photographic techniques

data.Name: Mineralogy, Point Counting
data.Description: Mineralogy determined via a point-counting method on thin sections. Point counting could be manual or automated.

data.Name: Mineralogy, Research And Development Method
data.Description: This value should be applied when the analysis method is not broadly known by the industry; For example, one service company or one operator is testing a new experimental method. It is expected that if a particular analysis method eventually becomes broadly used by the industry, that it will be contributed to the OSDU Forum and added to this SampleAnalysisType reference list.

data.Name: Mineralogy
data.Description: Mineralogy with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.

data.Name: Mineralogy, XRD
data.Description: XRD (X-ray Diffraction) is a technique for the mineralogical analysis of a sample by measuring the diffraction peaks in X-rays diffracted by the sample.

data.Name: Brine Permeability
data.Description: Permeability of a rock sample to brine (salt water similar to formation water or injection water); These experiments are typically carried out at several flow rates using simulated formation water.

data.Name: Petrography, Visual Kerogen
data.Description: Microscopic observations of isolated kerogens under transmitted white light to estimate the relative abundances of macerals such as vitrinite, inertinite, and amorphous organic matter (AOM).

data.Name: Petrography, Vitrinite Reflectance
data.Description: Vitrinite reflectance measures the percentage of incident light that is reflected from the surface of vitrinite as calibrated to a standard of known reflectance. This measurement is often regarded as the gold standard thermal maturity parameter and is used in oil and gas resource assessment and basin analysis studies.

data.Name: NMR
data.Description: Also known as Nuclear Magnetic Resonance. NMR with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or, c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily.")

data.Name: NMR, Research And Development Method
data.Description: This value should be applied when the analysis method is not broadly known by the industry; For example, one service company or one operator is testing a new experimental method. It is expected that if a particular analysis method eventually becomes broadly used by the industry, that it will be contributed to the OSDU Forum and added to this SampleAnalysisType reference list.

data.Name: Pyrolysis, Bulk
data.Description: Pyrolysis bulk methods include HAWK and RockEval. The goal is to screen rocks for organic richness. Typical results include S1, S2, S3, and Tmax measurements. The output could also include total organic carbon (TOC).

data.Name: Pyrolysis, Kinetics
data.Description: Pyrolysis laboratory measurements using instruments like Microscale Sealed Vessel (MSSV) and Source Rock Analyzer (SRA) are modelled to estimate the distribution of activation energy and frequency factors in immature source rocks samples for use in estimating hydrocarbon yield.

data.Name: Relative Permeability, Steady State
data.Description: Calculated using Darcy's law.  It assumes the saturation profile is homogeneous with the same pressure drop in each phrase.

data.Name: Relative Permeability, Single Speed Centrifuge
data.Description: Measuring the relative permeability on the displaced phase using a centrifuge at one rotational speed.

data.Name: Relative Permeability, Digital Rock Modelling
data.Description: Starting with scans or photography (e.g. CT) of physical samples, various digital models can be created and run to measure different properties digitally. Measurements often include pore scale modelling. Other existing measured data can be used to calibrate such a digital rock model.

data.Name: RelativePermeability, Unsteady State
data.Description: Unsteady state is a continuous single phase injection that does not achieve saturation equilibrium during the test.

data.Name: Grain Size Analysis, Dry Sieve Analysis
data.Description: Standard sieve analysis of a crushed sample

data.Name: Grain Size Analysis, Laser Particle Size Distribution Analysis
data.Description: Also known as LPSA. Grain size and sorting from LPSA on a crushed rock sample.

data.Name: Grain Size Analysis
data.Description: GrainSizeAnalysis with no SubFamily can be used when a) there is no conceptually valid subfamily for a given data set, b) the valid subfamily cannot be determined (for example if legacy metadata has been lost) or c) if no effort has been made to determine and assign a relevant subfamily. Note that grain density measured with routine core analysis is under the Family called "Basic Rock Properties".

data.Name: Stratigraphy, Biostratigraphic Analysis
data.Description: Biostratigraphy is the branch of stratigraphy which focuses on correlating and assigning relative ages of rock strata and their depositional environment by using the fossil assemblages contained within them.

data.Name: Stratigraphy, Sample Description
data.Description: Visual description of the sample

data.Name: Stratigraphy, SEM
data.Description: SEM is Scanning Electron Microscopy. Visual analysis of the pore and grain structure of a sample using an electron microscope. This includes FIB-SEM and FeSEM.

data.Name: Stratigraphy, Thin Section Description
data.Description: Analysis of a thin section of rock mounted on a slide to provide mineralogy, porosity, and structural features of the rock.

data.Name: Core Description
data.Description: Written and/or diagrammatic representation of the core to describe the lithologies, minerals, fractures, fossils, and structure of the core

data.Name: Isotope, Non Gas
data.Description: Isotope analysis (for example, d13C, dD, d34S) of a bulk sample, which might be a whole oil, saturate fraction, water, rock, etc.

data.Name: Elemental Composition, EDS Mapping
data.Description: Elemental Dispersive Spectroscopy technique applied to the surface of a thin section.

data.Name: Wettability, Amott Harvey
data.Description: Experiment which measures the interaction between two fluids and the rock sample surface by comparing the spontaneous imbibition of the two fluids.

data.Name: Wettability, Amott USBM
data.Description: Experiment which measures the interaction between two fluids and the rock sample surface by utilising the ratio of drainage to imbibition capillary pressure curves.
